rights.title: Right to Education
rights.description: Every child has the right to an education that develops their personality, talents and abilities to the fullest. Education should teach children to respect human rights and their own and other cultures. It should help them to live peacefully, protect the environment and respect other people.

articles.text: Children have the right to an education. Discipline in schools should respect children's human dignity. Primary education should be free. Wealthy countries should help poorer countries achieve this.
Education should develop each child's personality, talents and abilities to the fullest. It should encourage children to respect others' human rights and their own and other cultures.

examples.title: School for All Initiative
examples.description: In rural Ethiopia, a program has established over 1,000 community schools to ensure children in remote areas can access education, particularly focusing on girls who traditionally had lower enrollment rates.

examples.title: Digital Learning Bridge
examples.description: During the COVID-19 pandemic, Finland quickly transitioned to digital learning platforms, providing devices to students from low-income families to ensure educational continuity.

countries.name: Finland
countries.implementation: Universal free education with highly trained teachers and minimal standardized testing

countries.name: United States
countries.implementation: Public education system with significant disparities based on location and income

countries.name: India
countries.implementation: Right to Education Act guarantees free education, but implementation varies widely

countries.name: Niger
countries.implementation: Limited educational infrastructure with high gender disparities

challenges: 258 million children and youth are still out of school globally
Girls continue to face barriers to education in many regions
Children with disabilities often lack access to inclusive education
COVID-19 has disrupted education for 1.6 billion learners worldwide
Digital divide prevents many children from accessing online learning resources

rights.title: Right to Protection
rights.description: Children have the right to be protected from all forms of violence, abuse, neglect, and bad treatment. Governments must ensure that children are properly cared for and protected from violence, abuse and neglect by their parents or anyone else who looks after them.

articles.text: Governments should ensure that children are properly cared for and protect them from violence, abuse and neglect by their parents or anyone else who looks after them.
Governments should protect children from sexual abuse and exploitation.
Governments should take all measures possible to make sure that children are not abducted or sold.

examples.title: Child Protection Hotline
examples.description: Sweden established a 24/7 hotline specifically for children to report abuse or seek help, with trained counselors who can dispatch immediate assistance when needed.

examples.title: Community Guardian Program
examples.description: In Colombia, a network of community guardians has been trained to identify signs of child abuse and trafficking in high-risk areas, leading to a 30% reduction in child exploitation cases.

countries.name: Sweden
countries.implementation: Comprehensive child protection laws with strong enforcement and support services

countries.name: Australia
countries.implementation: National Framework for Protecting Australia's Children with coordinated approach

countries.name: Brazil
countries.implementation: Legal protections exist but enforcement is inconsistent across regions

countries.name: Afghanistan
countries.implementation: Limited legal framework with minimal enforcement capabilities

challenges: 1 billion children worldwide experience some form of violence each year
Child trafficking affects an estimated 1.2 million children annually
Online exploitation has increased dramatically with digital technology
Children in conflict zones face heightened risks of violence and abuse
Cultural practices in some regions can normalize harmful practices against children

rights.title: Right to Healthcare
rights.description: Every child has the right to the best possible health. Governments must provide good quality health care, clean water, nutritious food, and a clean environment and education on health and well-being so that children can stay healthy.

articles.text: Children have the right to good quality health care, clean water, nutritious food and a clean environment so that they will stay healthy. Richer countries should help poorer countries achieve this.
Governments should provide extra money for the children of families in need.

examples.title: Universal Child Healthcare
examples.description: Costa Rica provides universal healthcare to all children regardless of citizenship status, with mobile clinics reaching remote areas to ensure access for all children.

examples.title: School Nutrition Program
examples.description: Japan's national school lunch program ensures all children receive a nutritionally balanced meal daily, contributing to one of the lowest childhood obesity rates in the developed world.

countries.name: Norway
countries.implementation: Universal healthcare with specialized pediatric services and preventive care

countries.name: Thailand
countries.implementation: Universal coverage scheme that includes comprehensive child health services

countries.name: Mexico
countries.implementation: Seguro Popular program expanded coverage but quality varies by region

countries.name: Somalia
countries.implementation: Minimal healthcare infrastructure with heavy reliance on international aid

challenges: 5.2 million children under 5 die each year from preventable causes
149 million children under 5 suffer from stunting due to malnutrition
2 billion people lack access to safe drinking water
Healthcare access is severely limited in conflict zones and refugee settings
Climate change is creating new health threats for children globally

rights.title: Right to Expression
rights.description: Children have the right to express their opinions freely and to have their opinions considered in any matter affecting them. As their capacities develop, children should have increasing opportunities to participate in society's activities, in preparation for adulthood.

articles.text: Children have the right to give their opinions freely on issues that affect them. Adults should listen and take children seriously.
Children have the right to share freely with others what they learn, think and feel, by talking, drawing, writing or in any other way unless it harms other people.

examples.title: Youth Parliament
examples.description: The UK Youth Parliament allows young people aged 11-18 to be elected to represent their local area and debate issues that matter to them in the House of Commons annually.

examples.title: Children's News Network
examples.description: In South Korea, a national children's news network run entirely by children aged 10-16 reports on issues affecting young people, reaching millions of viewers weekly.

countries.name: Denmark
countries.implementation: Children's councils at local and national levels with meaningful input into policy

countries.name: Canada
countries.implementation: Various youth consultation mechanisms but limited direct impact on policy

countries.name: Tunisia
countries.implementation: Post-revolution reforms include youth participation structures

countries.name: Saudi Arabia
countries.implementation: Limited opportunities for children's expression, especially for girls

challenges: Cultural attitudes in many societies still view children's opinions as unimportant
Digital censorship restricts children's expression in many countries
Children from marginalized groups face additional barriers to being heard
School environments often discourage questioning and independent thinking
Children with disabilities frequently lack accessible communication channels

rights.title: Right to Play
rights.description: Children have the right to rest, relax, play and to take part in cultural and creative activities. Play is fundamental to children's physical, mental, and social development, helping them learn essential life skills in a natural way.

articles.text: Children have the right to rest, relax, play and to take part in cultural and creative activities.

examples.title: Urban Playground Initiative
examples.description: Barcelona has transformed 200 intersections into 'superblocks' - car-free play spaces where children can safely play outdoors in the urban environment.

examples.title: Play in Refugee Camps
examples.description: In Jordanian refugee camps, dedicated child-friendly spaces provide structured play opportunities for Syrian refugee children, helping them process trauma and maintain normal development.

countries.name: Netherlands
countries.implementation: National play policy with mandated play spaces in urban planning

countries.name: Japan
countries.implementation: Balance of academic focus with protected play time in early education

countries.name: Chile
countries.implementation: Growing recognition of play importance but limited infrastructure

countries.name: Bangladesh
countries.implementation: Play often sacrificed for work or academic pressure in many areas

challenges: Increasing academic pressure reduces time for unstructured play
Urbanization has reduced safe outdoor play spaces in many communities
Screen time is replacing physical play for many children worldwide
Child labor prevents millions of children from having time to play
Play is often not prioritized in humanitarian crises and emergency responses

rights.title: Right to Privacy
rights.description: Children have a right to privacy. The law should protect them from attacks against their way of life, their good name, their families and their homes. In the digital age, this extends to protection of their personal data and online activities.

articles.text: Children have the right to privacy. The law should protect them from attacks against their way of life, their good name, their families and their homes.

examples.title: Digital Privacy Education
examples.description: Germany has implemented a nationwide digital literacy curriculum that teaches children about online privacy, data protection, and how to safeguard their personal information online.

examples.title: Children's Data Protection Law
examples.description: South Korea's Youth Protection Revision Act specifically protects children's data online and requires parental consent for data collection from minors under 14.

countries.name: Germany
countries.implementation: Strong data protection laws specifically addressing children's privacy

countries.name: United Kingdom
countries.implementation: Age Appropriate Design Code sets standards for online services

countries.name: Argentina
countries.implementation: Personal Data Protection Law includes provisions for children

countries.name: China
countries.implementation: Growing regulations but extensive surveillance affects privacy

challenges: Digital platforms often collect extensive data from children without meaningful consent
Facial recognition and surveillance technologies increasingly target school environments
Parents often share children's information online without considering privacy implications
Many children lack understanding of digital privacy risks
Balancing safety monitoring with respect for privacy remains challenging

rights.title: Right to Identity
rights.description: Every child has the right to a name, nationality and family ties that are legally recognised and respected. This right ensures that children's personal identity is protected and preserved, including their name, nationality and family relations.

articles.text: Children have the right to a name, officially recognised by the government, and the right to a nationality and, as far as possible, to know and be cared for by their parents.
Governments must respect and protect children's identity, including their name, nationality and family ties.

examples.title: Birth Registration Campaign
examples.description: UNICEF's campaign in Mozambique increased birth registration rates from 31% to 70% in five years, ensuring children's legal identity and access to services.

examples.title: Stateless Children Support
examples.description: Thailand's legal reform in 2008 provided pathways to citizenship for stateless children born in the country, granting them access to education and healthcare.

countries.name: Netherlands
countries.implementation: Comprehensive birth registration system with near-universal coverage

countries.name: Ukraine
countries.implementation: Efforts to register children in conflict zones but challenges remain

countries.name: Dominican Republic
countries.implementation: Ongoing reforms to address statelessness among children of Haitian descent

countries.name: Myanmar
countries.implementation: Large populations of stateless children with limited access to registration

challenges: 166 million children under 5 were not registered at birth in 2019
Stateless children often lack access to education and healthcare
Conflict and displacement make it difficult to maintain legal identity
Discriminatory laws can deny nationality based on gender or ethnicity
Digital ID systems raise privacy and exclusion concerns if not implemented carefully

rights.title: Right to Participation
rights.description: Children have the right to express their views freely in all matters affecting them, to be heard, and to have their views taken seriously according to their age and maturity.

articles.text: Children have the right to give opinions on matters that affect them and to have those opinions taken into account.
Children have the right to freedom of expression and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds.

examples.title: Youth Climate Strikes
examples.description: Millions of children and youth participate in climate strikes worldwide, influencing climate policy discussions at national and international levels.

examples.title: Children's Municipal Councils
examples.description: In Norway, children's councils are elected in many municipalities to advise local governments on issues affecting young people.

countries.name: Sweden
countries.implementation: Strong youth participation mechanisms in schools and local government

countries.name: South Africa
countries.implementation: Children's Parliament provides input on national legislation

countries.name: Brazil
countries.implementation: Child participation recognized in statute but limited in practice

countries.name: Iran
countries.implementation: Few formal avenues for children to express views publicly

challenges: Cultural norms may discourage children from speaking up
Political environments can restrict freedom of expression
Digital divides limit participation via online platforms
Schools may prioritize rote learning over debate and dialogue
Marginalized children face additional barriers to participation

rights.title: Right to Family Unity
rights.description: Children have the right to live with their parents unless it is not in their best interests. Governments must respect the child's right to family relations and provide special protection if families cannot care for their children.

articles.text: Children must not be separated from their parents against their will, unless it is in the child's best interests (e.g., abuse or neglect).
Children who cannot be looked after by their own family have the right to special care and assistance provided by the state.

examples.title: Family Reunification Program
examples.description: Germany's humanitarian program reunites unaccompanied refugee children with their parents when possible, prioritising the child's best interests.

examples.title: Extended Family Foster Care
examples.description: In Kenya, government policy supports kinship care, allowing children to stay with relatives instead of institutional care whenever possible.

countries.name: New Zealand
countries.implementation: Strong family preservation and whƒÅnau (extended family) care policies

countries.name: Spain
countries.implementation: Family reunification rights protected in immigration law, though delays occur

countries.name: Philippines
countries.implementation: Labour migration separates many families; government offers support programs

countries.name: Syria
countries.implementation: Conflict has displaced millions of children from their parents

challenges: Armed conflict and migration separate millions of families
Administrative barriers delay family reunification for refugee children
Poverty can lead to unnecessary separation through institutionalisation
LGBTQ+ parents may face legal hurdles to maintain family ties
COVID-19 travel restrictions disrupted family unity across borders

rights.title: Rights of Refugee & Migrant Children
rights.description: Children who are refugees or migrants have the right to special protection and assistance, including access to education, healthcare and protection from exploitation.

articles.text: Children who are refugees or seeking asylum are entitled to appropriate protection and humanitarian assistance.

examples.title: Education Cannot Wait Fund
examples.description: Global fund provides schooling for 4 million displaced children in crisis zones like Yemen and Syria.

examples.title: Health Access for Rohingya Children
examples.description: Bangladesh and NGOs run immunisation drives for Rohingya refugee children in Cox's Bazar camps.

countries.name: Canada
countries.implementation: Provides universal healthcare and schooling for asylum-seeking children

countries.name: Turkey
countries.implementation: Hosts 3.6 million Syrian refugees; children have access to public schools with language support

countries.name: Greece
countries.implementation: Overcrowded island camps limit children's access to basic services

countries.name: Libya
countries.implementation: Detention of migrant children and lack of services

challenges: Protracted conflicts displace children for years without stable services
Border pushbacks and detention violate child protection standards
Language barriers impede education and health access
Statelessness risk for children born in exile
Mental health impacts of trauma and uncertainty

rights.title: Rights of Children with Disabilities
rights.description: Children with disabilities have the right to full inclusion and participation in society, access to specialized services, and protection from discrimination.

articles.text: Children with disabilities have the right to special care and support so they can live full and independent lives.

examples.title: Inclusive Education Model
examples.description: Portugal transformed most special schools into inclusive schools, integrating 99% of students with disabilities in mainstream classrooms.

examples.title: Accessible Playgrounds Initiative
examples.description: The United States' "Kiwanis Miracle League" builds universal-design playgrounds so children of all abilities can play together.

countries.name: Finland
countries.implementation: Comprehensive inclusive education with personalised support

countries.name: Morocco
countries.implementation: National strategy for disability rights but limited rural reach

countries.name: India
countries.implementation: Right to Education Act includes provisions for children with disabilities but resource gaps remain

countries.name: Yemen
countries.implementation: Conflict and poverty severely restrict services for children with disabilities

challenges: 150 million children live with some form of disability worldwide
Stigma and discrimination limit participation in many societies
Lack of accessible infrastructure and learning materials
Higher risk of violence and neglect
Under-resourcing of specialised services in low-income countries
